game

Class Sprite

  • java.lang.Object
    • game.Sprite

  • public class Sprite
extends java.lang.Object
    This class is where we load and scale all of our images.
    Author:
    Clayton Nida

      Sprite()

    • Constructor Detail

      • Sprite

        public Sprite()

    • Method Detail

      • loadSprite

        public static java.awt.image.BufferedImage loadSprite(java.lang.String file,
                                                      java.lang.String character)
        This will take the given String's file and character and use these to load the correct images. It will then pass these images along to Sprite's scale(...) method to scale the images to the correct sizes, while keeping them smooth.
        Parameters:
        file - The file String to load from.
        character - The character used to identify what images to load.
        Returns:
        Returns the loaded image.

      • scale

        private static java.awt.image.BufferedImage scale(java.awt.image.BufferedImage image,
                                                  int width,
                                                  int height,
                                                  int smoothingSteps)
        This will scale a given image to a given width and height. It will do this a given number of times to make the image appear smoother.
        Parameters:
        image - The image being scaled.
        width - The width to scale to.
        height - The height to scale to.
        smoothingSteps - How many times to draw the image, so that it doesn't appear ragged.
        Returns:
        Returns a method call to draw(...) with the newly scaled/smoothed image, and it's width and height.

      • draw

        private static java.awt.image.BufferedImage draw(java.awt.image.BufferedImage image,
                                                 int w,
                                                 int h)
        This will redraw the image passed to it.
        Parameters:
        image - Image to be drawn.
        w - Width of the image in pixels.
        h - Height of the image in pixels.
        Returns:
        The newly drawn image.
